bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Carlos E. Finlay, August 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg thanks Finlay for his letter and assures him that his opinion was welcomed. He discusses the possibility of a second yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Carlos E. Finlay, August 27, 1941
div1.opener:
August 27, 1941
Dr. C. E. Finlay,
Linea Numero 710
Vedado, Havana, Cuba
My dear Dr. Finlay:
div1.p:
Your letter of August 21 is much appre-
ciated. You may be assured that we welcome your outspoken
opinions at any time. Our good friend, Dr. Philip S. Hench
of the Mayo Clinic repeatedly suggested to me that we should do
do two paintings on the yellow fever subject in order to cover
it competently. The first sketch of which you spoke--that of
your father presenting the mosquito eggs to the Yellow Fever
Commission would, along with the present one, give a complete
story. It may be possible that I can obtain the money for
this purpose at some later date, but it is impossible now.

I much appreciated receiving the talk on
Dr. Finlay read at the New Orleans Lions Club Convention.

Together with the speech given by Dr. Hench
in Cleveland, Ohio, at the time of the unveiling, “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” will appear in the health magazine, HYGEIA,
for October.

The picture will also be reproduced in a
late October issue of the JOURNAL of the AMERICAN MEDICAL
ASSOCIATION. I shall take pleasure in seeing to it that you
receive a copy of each.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg GAK:L
